tossups.question: Allan Bloom infamously claimed that young people enjoyed rock music and this classical work because of their "sexual" rhythm. From about halfway in this composition onward, the theme is progressively doubled in the keys of the tonic's first through fourth overtones. This piece is the most popular to call for the F major sopranino saxophone. Though this piece's composer apocryphally praised a woman at its premiere for shouting that he was mad, he also rebuked Toscanini for performing it too fast. This piece emerged from a commission from ballerina Ida Rubinstein to orchestrate parts of Isaac Albeniz's Iberia. The composer's progressive aphasia may have inspired this piece's structure of "one very long, gradual crescendo." For 10 points, a repetitive snare ostinato underlines what piece named for a Spanish dance by Maurice Ravel?
tossups.formatted_answer: Bolero
tossups.answer: Bolero

tossups.question: Eberhard Grün measured the distribution in sizes in this substance. Venetia Burney names a device used to detect this substance, which was collected in the first phase of the Tanpopo experiment. One of this substance's components is abbreviated GEMS (gee ee em ess). A perfect fluid modeled as a configuration of this substance with vanishing pressure is a namesake solution to the Einstein field equations. A NASA probe launched in 1999 collected this substance using silica aerogel. This substance loses angular momentum due to radiation pressure in the Poynting-Robertson effect. This substance scatters sunlight to produce zodiacal light. Interstellar reddening occurs due to scattering by this substance, which makes up the interstellar medium along with gas and cosmic rays. For 10 points, name this substance made up of particles in outer space.
tossups.formatted_answer: cosmic dust [or extraterrestrial dust or space dust or dust particles or interplanetary dust]
tossups.answer: cosmic dust [or extraterrestrial dust or space dust or dust particles or interplanetary dust]

tossups.question: William Hazlitt's edition of a poem by this author discusses a musical setting of it by Dr. John Wilson and bemoans the text's "extraordinary corruption," while swapping the word "gods" for "birds" in the first stanza. This poet created a speaker who "with shriller throat shall sing" like "committed linnets" of the "glories of my King." This poet borrowed William Habington's image of "the nunnery of thy chaste breast" in one poem, while another poem by this author claims that "fishes that tipple in the deep" and "birds that wanton in the air...know no such liberty" as its speaker. This author, who wrote a poem that ends, "I could not love thee, Dear, so much, lov'd I not Honour more," declared that "stone walls do not a prison make" in another poem. For 10 points, name this Cavalier poet who wrote "To Althea, from Prison."
tossups.formatted_answer: Richard Lovelace ("loveless")
tossups.answer: Richard Lovelace ("loveless")

tossups.question: In Tagalog myth, a hybrid of a man and this creature can be tamed by plucking three of its spines. That Tikbalang may have been inspired by an avatar of Vishnu with this creature's head who returns stolen Vedas to Brahma and sometimes kills a davana also named Hayagriva. An iron prosthetic leg is given to one of these creatures who either is Vishpala or accompanies her. Alongside elephants and the cow Kamadhenu, the churning of the milk ocean produces one of these creatures named Uchchaihshravas (UCH-chai-SHRA-vuss) who has seven heads. The chief queen spends a night next to one of these creatures suffocated to death after it spends a year wandering in the Vedic ritual of Ashvamedha. A white one of these animals called Devadatta appears at the end of the Kali Yuga, carrying Kalki. For 10 points, name these animals that pull Arjuna's chariot.
tossups.formatted_answer: horses
tossups.answer: horses

tossups.question: This leader had members of TsUNKhu (t'SUN-koo) arrested after a census revealed a population decrease. New York Times reporter Walter Duranty openly disputed Gareth Jones's account of a disaster under this leader's regime exacerbated by the Law of Spikelets (spike-lets). A German-arranged commission investigating a separate mass execution under this leader's regime discovered the remnants of the Vinnytsia (vin-ITZ-uh) massacre also perpetrated by this man's regime. During this man's time in office, the Shakhty Trial and other accusations of "wrecking" constituted part of the Great Purge. The Holodomor (hah-luh-doh-MOR) occurred under this leader, who initially closed churches to advance state atheism under his Second Five-Year Plan prior to reversing course during the Great Patriotic War. For 10 points, name this dictator of the Soviet Union throughout the 1930s and World War II.
tossups.formatted_answer: Joseph Stalin [Joseph Vissarionovich Stalin; or Ioseb Besarionis dze Jughashvili]

tossups.question: This process is initiated by the M·p·s·1 kinase acting as a "mechanical switch." This process occurs smoothly if there is amphitelic attachment. A lysine-glutamate-asparagine motif, or K·E·N box, is targeted by a complex that initiates this process. A protein targeted in this process is partially protected by Shugoshin. This process, which begins after S·A·C, is promoted by the activation of a complex by C·D·C·20. Immediately before this process, the cyclosome is inhibited until bi-orientation occurs, then A·P·C/C ubiquitinates securin to release separase. When this process does not occur properly, it can result in nondisjunctions. During this process, cohesin is broken down and microtubules attached to the kinetochore (kin-ET-oh-core) pull apart sister chromatids. For 10 points, name this phase of mitosis and meiosis which comes after metaphase.
tossups.formatted_answer: anaphase [or anaphase I or II; prompt on meiosis; prompt on mitosis; prompt on ubiquitination until amphitelic is read]

tossups.question: This philosopher praised Eugen Fink's addition of a sixth entry to a series in which this thinker describes how intersubjectivity constructs objective reality, as later elaborated by his student Edith Stein. Franz Brentano's concept of intentionality is extended in this thinker's difficult-to-decipher conception of "noema" and its relation to "noesis." Heidegger originally dedicated Being and Time to this thinker, who turned two Sorbonne lectures into a set of five "meditations" modeled on the Meditations on First Philosophy. This philosopher sought to found all sciences on a "Transcendental Subjectivity" developed by suspending previous beliefs about phenomena, a method he termed "epoche" or "bracketing." For 10 points, name this author of Logical Investigations and Cartesian Meditations who founded modern phenomenology.
tossups.formatted_answer: Edmund Husserl [or Edmund Gustav Albrecht Husserl] (Heidegger's dedication was later rescinded on account of Husserl's Jewish ancestry)
tossups.answer: Edmund Husserl [or Edmund Gustav Albrecht Husserl] (Heidegger's dedication was later rescinded on account of Husserl's Jewish ancestry)

tossups.question: A character who attempts to do an extreme form of this action constantly rewatches Whoopi Goldberg videotapes and befriends the conceptual artist Ping Xi (shee). This action is the last word in the title of a 1934 novel about the childhood of Jewish immigrant David Schearl. In pre-9/11 New York, a friend of Reva pursues an extreme form of this action in a 2018 novel by Ottessa Moshfegh. Henry Roth's most popular novel is titled Call It this action. Mona "Silver-Wig" Mars frees the hero of a novel partly titled for this action, in which Carmen kills Rusty following the involvement of her father, General Sternwood. That 1939 hardboiled crime novel titled for this action introduced the investigator Philip Marlowe. Raymond Chandler wrote a novel titled for a Big example of, for 10 points, what action performed by Rip Van Winkle for twenty years?
tossups.formatted_answer: sleeping [or resting; or relaxing; or word forms; or Call It Sleep or The Big Sleep; prompt on death by asking, "What action literally appears in the novel's title?"] [Moshfegh's novel is My Year of Rest and Relaxation, whose protagonist tries to sleep for a year.]

tossups.question: Homothetic preferences are guaranteed by a utility function for which a property named for this process is constant, as used in the Dixit-Stiglitz model. With "industrialization," this process names a policy motivated by the Prebisch-Singer hypothesis in development economics, by which domestic production increases in order to decrease imports. Along an isoquant, the "technical rate" of this process is constant. Linear, negatively sloping indifference curves guarantee this process occurs "perfectly" because of a positive cross elasticity of demand. A change in the relative price of goods causes an effect named for this process, which is usually paired with the income effect. For 10 points, name this process which names pairs of goods such as butter and margarine that are easily swapped, in contrast to complementary goods.
tossups.formatted_answer: substitution [accept word forms such as substitutes; accept constant elasticity of substitution; accept import substitution industrialization]

tossups.question: A 2019 book by Colin Gordon on the racial history of this city documents Esther Brooks's failed attempts to stop "urban renewal" of its Elmwood Park neighborhood under Harland Bartholomew. A group called ACTION staged protests to have this city hire Black workers to build a monument. After Black workers in this city were hired as replacements for striking aluminum-ore processors, dozens of its Black community were murdered in a 1917 race massacre. The 1948 case that overturned the use of racial covenants, Shelley v. Kraemer, originated from this city. Muggers took advantage of the skip-stop elevators in a neglected public housing complex in this city that was demolished in 1972. Pruitt-Igoe was located in, for 10 points, what city where Black neighborhoods were demolished to make way for the Gateway Arch?
tossups.formatted_answer: St. Louis
tossups.answer: St. Louis

tossups.question: A "Central" mosque in this city was built in a neo-Ottoman style with concrete shells interspersed with glass walls. Three glass towers in this city extend over a river, appearing like "crane houses." A shopping venue in this city called the WDR Arcades has a facade appearing like a water ripple. Coosje van Bruggen (KOHSH-yuh van BREW-hen) and Claes (CLAYZ) Oldenburg placed a giant sculpture of an inverted ice cream cone on top of a shopping mall in this city. A building in this city contains St. Peter's Bell and a golden triple sarcophagus. That building in this city also houses the ~Gero Crucifix~ and the "Shrine of the Three Kings." Gerhard Richter designed a stained-glass window for a building in this city whose twin finials once made it the tallest building in the world. For 10 points, name this German city on the Rhine home to a massive Gothic cathedral.

tossups.question: A set of parameters for an equation that calculates this quantity can be found using the T·C·P·C model. At high concentrations, this quantity can be computed using the Bromley equation, which adds an interaction term beta times lowercase b term. This quantity is split into a "combinatorial" and a "residual" component in the UNIFAC model. This quantity is often computed in a state of infinite dilution. The natural log of this quantity is proportional to the square of the charge number of the ion species and the square root of the ionic strength in the Debye-Hückel (duh-BYE-HUCK-uhl) equation. With impure liquids, this quantity is multiplied by the mole fraction of the component in solution by a modification of Raoult's (rah-OO's) law. tossups.question: Stone examples of these structures may be made of five blocks shaped to symbolize each of the five elements. A bell named for resting in turtle farmland was built for a place commonly named for being one of these structures resting on a single pillar. In Japan, model stone examples of these structures are called sekito, while full-size examples were once the centerpiece of shichido garan before the kondo took their place. The concept of Uppatasanti (oo-PAH-tuh-san-tee) names one of these buildings that is a replica of a gilded example called Shwedagon (shuh-WED-uh-gon) that is found in Yangon. Frescoes depicting scenes from Journey to the West appear in an octagonal brick building of this type in Kaifeng (kai-FONG) named for looking like it is made of iron. tossups.formatted_answer: pagodas [prompt on stupas before mention]

tossups.question: An author born in this country proposed that "the rhythm of the sound" is the "sixth character" in one of his plays, in which a man called Trumpet carries around a trumpet while working as an assistant train conductor. In a play from this country, a plastic sheet brought by the Carpenter lets characters take shelter from rain. Before moving to France, an author from this country wrote Absolute Signal and a play in which the Old Man claims he's going to play a chess match while Hothead and Glasses wait for ten years at the title Bus Stop. Eight "model plays" from this country, including On the Docks, The Legend of the Red Lantern and The Red Detachment of Women, were popularized by its Communist Party. For 10 points, name this country whose author Gao Xingjian (GOW shing-JYAN) was influenced by the Cultural Revolution.

tossups.question: Harvard professor Gary Urton created an extensive database cataloging over 700 of these objects, almost 300 of which are in the Ethnological Museum of Berlin. William Glynn claims to have deciphered words in these objects based on patterns in a chronicle by Guamán Poma (gwah-MAH poh-mah). Marcia and Robert Ascher's system for understanding these objects used the designation "EE" to identify a configuration with an extra twist. Evidence for a writing system in these objects include a three-number sequence possibly representing the village of Puruchuco (poo-roo-CHOO-koh). The pututu (poo-TOO-too) instrument and these objects were carried by teen-aged chasquis (CHAH-skees). Figure-eights have a value of one on these objects, which were sometimes made of fibers spun from alpaca or llama hair. For 10 points, name this system of knotted strings used to communicate throughout the Incan empire.
tossups.formatted_answer: quipu (KEE-poo) [prompt on strings; prompt on knots; prompt on ropes]

tossups.question: The Vitruvian man inspired Tony Smith to make a steel sculpture of one of these objects titled Die (dai). Sol LeWitt frequently made "modular" sculptures named for these objects, which also name a 28-part series of steel sculptures by David Smith. One of these objects is elongated and sits on a slotted spoon on the title Glass of Absinthe in six works by a sculptor who, like Alexander Archipenko and Jacque Lipchitz, was part of an art movement named for them. Critic Louis Vauxcelles (voh-SELL) recounted how Henri Matisse mocked a rejected entry to the Salon d'Automne as a "painting made of" these "little" objects. "Analytic" and "Synthetic" divisions of a movement named for these things were proposed by Juan Gris. tossups.question: This character, described as someone who "no longer expects anything of anything," is discreetly given documents after Anatoly Anatolin claims that "the gardens are always under close observation." Along with a woman who calls herself Corinna, Gertrude, and Ingrid, this character is arrested by "fake police" during a country's revolution. A character who teaches himself not to read, Irnerio, informs this character that his lover often travels to Switzerland to meet Silas Flannery. This character is invited to a university to meet with a professor of Cimmerian literature, Uzzi-Tuzii. This character, who ultimately marries Ludmilla, encounters several counterfeit books while searching for the original. tossups.question: The Split Apple Rock is located in a bay named for this man near a national park due south of the Farewell Spit. Another national park named for this man contains a dolerite sea stack called The Totem Pole. The volcano remnant Ball's Pyramid is located in a sea named for this man known colloquially as "The Ditch." The population of an animal native to a region named for this man has been ravaged by a namesake "Facial Tumor Disease" and is the largest carnivorous marsupial in the world. This man names the sea that contains Lord Howe Island and the largest glacier on the South Island. An island named for this man contains the Bay of Fires and a rainforest called the Tarkine (tar-KEEN). Hobart (HOH-burt) is the capital of an island named for this man formerly called Van Diemen's ("demon's") Land. For 10 points, what 17th-century Dutch explorer names an island state of Australia?

tossups.question: Following one of these events and a subsequent slave revolt, King Archidamus II (ARK-id-AH-moos the second) was credited with saving an affected city after rejecting assistance from Cimon (KEE-mahn). Consul Marcus Vergilianus was killed in one of these events in Antioch that emperor Trajan escaped with only minor injuries. Athenian hoplite support was turned away in 464 BC by Spartan elites suppressing a helot uprising that occurred after one of these events, further straining relations prior to the Peloponnesian War. The Colossus of Rhodes toppled over due to one of these events, another of which in Potidaea (poh-tee-aid-AI-uh) in 479 BC coincided with the oldest record of a tsunami. For 10 points, name these natural disasters thought to be caused by Poseidon's trident, thus earning the god the name "earth shaker."

tossups.question: Jucys (YUT-sis) diagrams illustrate computations involving this quantity, which can be simplified with Racah-W coefficients. Operators written in this quantity's eigenbasis (EYE-gun-base-iss) can be expressed in terms of reduced matrix elements using the Wigner-Eckart theorem. The components of this quantity's operator all commute with its square, but not with each other. The quantum operator for this quantity equals "minus i h-bar times x crossed with the gradient operator." This quantity is quantized as integer multiples of the reduced Planck constant in the Bohr model of the atom. Measurements of this quantity correspond to the azimuthal and magnetic quantum numbers, written as "j" and "l." This quantity is classically defined as the product of mass, velocity, and radius. For 10 points, name this quantity, an "intrinsic" type of which is spin.
tossups.formatted_answer: angular momentum [or orbital angular momentum or spin angular momentum or angular momentum operator; or L or J until they are read; antiprompt on spin]

tossups.question: The international standard for this element's abundance is based on the isotopic ratio of 22.22 observed in the Canyon Diablo meteorite. The Ukrainian scientist Sergei Winogradsky pioneered "life cycles" by studying how this element was used by Beggiatoa (BEJ-ah-TOE-ah), which thrives in euxinic (yook-ZIN-ik) conditions. This is the heaviest element in the compound central to the CLAW hypothesis, which concerns a negative feedback loop involving its emission by phytoplankton. Aerosols of this element would be injected into the stratosphere in a plan to slow climate change. The strongest known greenhouse gas is the hexafluoride of this element, which is bonded to mercury in cinnabar (SIN-uh-bar). Nitrogen oxides and this element's oxides are the main contributors to acid rain. For 10 points, name this element whose atmospheric presence smells like rotten eggs.
tossups.formatted_answer: sulfur [or S; antiprompt on sulfates or sulfides]

bonuses.leadin: A leader of this expedition beat Charles Gray after Gray stole skilligolee (SKIL-ee-goh-lee) porridge and contracted dysentery. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this failed 1860s expedition which is commemorated on the Dig Tree. The Irish soldier John King was the only man to successfully see this expedition to fruition.
The Burke and Wills expedition sought to cross this continent from south to north. The expedition's destination was the Gulf of Carpentaria and it began at this continent's city of Melbourne.

The Burke and Wills expedition tried and failed several times to reach the outpost at Mount Hopeless, which was reached by this other explorer. This man, the namesake of a feature now also known as Kati Thanda, effected martial law in order to suppress the Morant Bay Rebellion while governor of Jamaica.
answers: Burke and Wills expedition [or answers describing the expedition of Robert O'Hara Burke and William John Wills; or Victorian Exploring Expedition]
formatted_answers: Burke and Wills expedition [or answers describing the expedition of Robert O'Hara Burke and William John Wills; or Victorian Exploring Expedition]

bonuses.leadin: In Islamic tradition, this prophet is known as "the painter" because of the illustrations in his holy Book of Pictures, or Arzhang. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this prophet whose Shabuhragan is dedicated to Shapur I (“the first”). His teachings were spread by Faustus of Mileve, one of the "electi" whose food had to be harvesters by an "auditor."

Though the Manichaean Bishop Faustus failed to impress Augustine of Hippo, he did not turn to Christianity until reading this epistle's chapter 13 in Italy. A landmark study by Karl Barth is titled for this letter to a coincidentally Italian city.

The world is called "enemy-occupied territory" after this book describes Manichean dualism as the "most sensible creed" behind Christ. C.S. Lewis's namesake "trilemma" was presented in this book compiled from radio talks.
answers: Epistle to the Romans [or Letter of Paul to the Romans; or Book of Romans; or Pros Romaious]
formatted_answers: Epistle to the Romans [or Letter of Paul to the Romans; or Book of Romans; or Pros Romaious]

bonuses.leadin: The Sherrington-Kirkpatrick model shows how spin glasses can be affected by this phenomenon, which can lead to a multiplicity of ground states. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this phenomenon from condensed matter physics, in which all interaction energies in a system cannot be simultaneously minimized, leading to potentially complex structures.
Geometrical frustration commonly affects the "anti" form of this phenomenon. Iron and cobalt display this permanent form of magnetism.

Simple models for geometric frustration usually consider coupling either of spin or of this quantity. This vector quantity, often symbolized by mu, represents the strength of a permanent magnet, such that the potential energy is equal to the dot product of this quantity and the magnetic field.

bonuses.leadin: Description acceptable. Moira Johnston's book Spectral Evidence covers the case of Gary Ramona, who sued his daughter's psychiatrist for performing this action. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this action criticized in Richard Ofshe's book Making Monsters. A book co-written with Katherine Ketcham analyzes how therapists can perform this action through techniques like hypnosis.

This psychologist co-wrote The Myth of Repressed Memory with Ketcham. Along with her student Jim Coan, this psychologist successfully implanted false memories in subjects in the "lost in the mall" experiment.
Because of her research on false memories, Loftus was strongly critical of the use of these people who provide testimony in court cases.
answers: implanting false memories [accept descriptive equivalents such as creating false memories; prompt on answers describing drawing out repressed memories]
formatted_answers: implanting false memories [accept descriptive equivalents such as creating false memories; prompt on answers describing drawing out repressed memories]

bonuses.leadin: This poem describes a sailor "smoking his pipe" and "thinking about the beaches" of a "vague, distant, misty country." For 10 points each:
parts: Name this poem, which opens by describing how "the sea like a vast silvered mirror reflects the sky like a sheet of zinc."
This Nicaraguan poet of "Symphony in Gray Major" criticized American imperialism in "To Roosevelt" and wrote the collection Azul... (ah-SOOL), which helped kickstart modernismo in poetry.

One modernist element that Darío incorporated into "Symphony in Gray Major" was to combine words stressed on the antepenultimate syllable with this type of rhyme, which contrasts with consonance because only the vowels match.

bonuses.leadin: Archedemos made the Vari Cave into a shrine while allegedly possessed by these beings. For 10 points each:
parts: Name these beings, to whom grottoes such as "Coventina's Well" were dedicated. A Greek word for "bride" covers the range of these minor nature deities, who were divided into such groups as dryads and oreads.
In medieval and modern times, Greeks adopted the name of these nymphs for faeries that ranged from mischievous to malevolent. These fifty daughters of Doris include Thetis and Galatea.

By claiming this woman was more beautiful than them, her mother angered the Nereids. The Egyptian god Ammon's oracle tells her father Cepheus to chain her to a rock, but she is soon rescued from the monster Cetus.

bonuses.leadin: As played by the Ferranti Mark 1, this tune, followed by "Baa Baa Black Sheep" and a short version of Glenn Miller's "In the Mood," constitutes the earliest surviving music played and recorded on a computer. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this song attributed to John Bull, which is quoted alongside "Rule Britannia" to represent England in Wellington's Victory. Its tune is shared by "My Country 'Tis Of Thee."
This composer quoted "God Save the King" throughout his "Great National Symphony." This "Father of the Piano's" Opus 36 consists of six simple sonatinas for piano.

This composer's time in England inspired his hymn "God Save Emperor Francis," which later became the "Deutschlandlied." Variations on that hymn appear in one of the Erdödy Quartets by this "father of the string quartet."
answers: "God Save the Queen" [or "God Save the King"]
formatted_answers: "God Save the Queen" [or "God Save the King"]

bonuses.leadin: This character, who works in a shoe factory after moving from Wisconsin to Chicago, is convinced by Charlie Drouet (DROO-ay) to appear in an amateur production of Under the Gaslight. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this character, who becomes a well-known actress after moving to New York City with her husband, George Hurstwood.
This naturalist author wrote Sister Carrie and An American Tragedy.

After stealing ten thousand dollars from a safe at work, George takes Carrie to this city, where they get married. In another novel, a character whose Apprenticeship occurs in this city's Jewish ghetto becomes obsessed with the saying, "A man without land is nobody."

bonuses.leadin: Though the Dzungars had switched to muskets, the victorious Qing army at the Battle of Khorgos was largely made of these soldiers. For 10 points each:
parts: Identify this type of soldier who adopted thumb rings because of their usage of a "Mongolian draw." The Parthians name a tactic of attacking during retreat used by these warriors.

These troops were probably developed in Persia to counter horse archers, since, as their Greek name suggests, their heavy armor protected them from arrows. These cavalrymen were later adopted by the Byzantines.
Genoese mercenaries who wielded these weapons were often employed against horse archers, since footmen had a rather easy time hitting large targets with bolts from these mechanical ranged weapons.
answers: horse archers [or mounted archers; or answers describing bow and arrow-wielding soldiers riding an animal; prompt on archer; prompt on cavalry; prompt on horsemen]
formatted_answers: horse archers [or mounted archers; or answers describing bow and arrow-wielding soldiers riding an animal; prompt on archer; prompt on cavalry; prompt on horsemen]

bonuses.leadin: Atoms of this element characterize a stable heterocyclic class of compounds called NHCs, whose most widely researched varieties are derived from imidazole. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this element present in the heterocycle of true alkaloids. The pyrimidine and purine bases found in DNA contain two and four atoms of this element, respectively.

NHCs are among the most stable of these compounds, in contrast to previous types investigated by Fischer and Shrock. Hans-Werner Wanzlick proposed that these compounds form a reversible equilibrium via dimerization.
Most NHC ligands are synthesized by making this modification to their respective azolium salt. When performed on an enol, this modification generates the conjugate enolate ion.
answers: deprotonation [or removing a proton; accept H+ or hydrogen atom in place of proton]
formatted_answers: deprotonation [or removing a proton; accept H+ or hydrogen atom in place of proton]

bonuses.leadin: Donald Davidson described this person's "effect" as discovering that they had already come up with your supposedly novel philosophical idea. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this polymath who died at age 26. Graham's number arises in a mathematical "theory" named for this man, which is based on a theorem about finding monochromatic cliques in sufficiently large graphs.

Ramsey worked with C. K. Ogden to make the first English translation of this short 1921 book, whose first numbered proposition states that "the world is everything that is the case" and whose last states "what we cannot speak of, we must pass over in silence."
Ramsey convinced this Austrian author of Tractatus Logico-Philosophicus and Philosophical Investigations to return to Cambridge.
answers: Frank P. Ramsey [accept Ramsey theory or Ramsey's theorem or the Ramsey effect]
formatted_answers: Frank P. Ramsey [accept Ramsey theory or Ramsey's theorem or the Ramsey effect]

bonuses.leadin: This artist's sculpture Christus shows the Messiah with outstretched arms and was adopted as the logo of the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-Day Saints. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this Neoclassical sculptor who designed a rock relief of a weeping lion beside Lake Lucerne to memorialize Swiss Guards.
Thorvaldsen's early work Cupid and Psyche was created a year after this sculptor's Psyche Revived by Cupid's Kiss located at the Louvre. This sculptor created Venus Victrix.
Thorvaldsen hails from this country, whose capital contains an oft-vandalized Edvard Eriksen sculpture of The Little Mermaid on a rock.

bonuses.leadin: Las Vegas Gazette publisher J. H. Koogler embellished the exploits of this figure, who was a member of a group called the Regulators. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this Wild West outlaw who was only 21 years old when he was killed in Fort Sumner by Pat Garrett.

This governor of the New Mexico Territory offered a 500 dollar reward for the capture of Billy the Kid. This man, who arrived late to the Battle of Shiloh, wrote a popular 1880 historical novel subtitled "A Tale of the Christ" that features a chariot race won by a Jewish prince.
Billy the Kid was a prominent participant in this New Mexico conflict, which included a five-day gun battle. This conflict began in 1878 when a posse tried to seize the livestock of John Tunstall.
answers: Billy the Kid [or Henry McCarty; or Henry Antrim; or Kid Antrim; or William H. Bonney; prompt on "Billy"; prompt on "The Kid"]
formatted_answers: Billy the Kid [or Henry McCarty; or Henry Antrim; or Kid Antrim; or William H. Bonney; prompt on "Billy"; prompt on "The Kid"]

bonuses.leadin: If the hawk-dove game is symmetric, then this strategy is simply the mixed Nash equilibrium. For 10 points each:
parts: Name these strategies co-developed by George Price. These strategies, which are refinements of Nash equilibria, cannot be replaced by any mutant alternative strategy.

John Maynard Smith showed that evolutionarily stable strategies are preserved in a population just through this process, where individuals with advantageous phenotypes reproducing more often. Charles Darwin showed that it formed the basis for evolution.

A common example of evolutionary stable strategies concerns this quantity, which can be changed via selective infanticide to improve fitness. Smith and Price's work was inspired by Fisher's principle, which explains why this quantity is usually about 1.
answers: sex ratio [or ratio of males to females or ratio of females to males or equivalents]
formatted_answers: sex ratio [or ratio of males to females or ratio of females to males or equivalents]

bonuses.leadin: David Sylvester named a cultural movement for these objects in reference to John Bratby's depressing painting of one. For 10 points each:
parts: Name these objects, which describe a genre of gritty working-class drama exemplified by Shelagh (SHEE-la) Delaney's play A Taste of Honey.
A woman burns her arm on an iron in this pioneering kitchen sink drama, which depicts the effects of class pressures on Alison and Jimmy Porter.

In A Taste of Honey, a character with this first name worries about future economic pressures after getting pregnant. A member of the March family with this first name, the sister of Meg, Beth, and Amy, becomes a writer in Little Women.

bonuses.leadin: In his book Political Theology, this lapsed Catholic equated "the modern theory of the state" to "secularized theological concepts," with the state taking God's place as subject. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this authoritarian whose The Concept of the Political introduced the friend-enemy distinction often invoked in discussions of the contemporary foreign policy of China and Russia.

While in the Nazi Party, Schmitt wrote a critique of the mechanistic conception of the state in this Thomas Hobbes book, beginning with a religious analysis of the title creature from Abrahamic tradition.
Schmitt nonetheless praised Hobbes alongside this Italian Counter-Enlightenment philosopher, who proposed collapsing the humanities into a singular study of the cycle of history in The New Science.
answers: Leviathan or The Matter, Forme and Power of a Commonwealth Eclesiasticall and Civil
formatted_answers: Leviathan or The Matter, Forme and Power of a Commonwealth Eclesiasticall and Civil

bonuses.leadin: This man one-upped his collaborator by using parts from an old Chevy to create the first multiplane camera. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this special effects technician who used the sodium vapor process he co-developed to finish the shots of attacking avians in Alfred Hitchcock's The Birds. This man created Oswald the Lucky Rabbit, co-created Walt Disney's Mickey Mouse, and animated almost all of Steamboat Willie.
Mickey and Oswald's past is explored in Warren Spector's Epic Mickey, which was exclusive to this console. uDraw on this console required pointing a remote.

Walt and Roy Disney helped to found this college in Santa Clarita. Fans of "rubber hose" animation are wont to denigrate its namesake "thin-line" animation style as used by graduates Alex Hirsch and Pendleton Ward.
answers: Ub Iwerks (UBB EYE-"works") [or Ubbe Ert Iwwerks; or U. B. Iwerks]
CalArts [or California Institute of the Arts; accept CalArts style]
formatted_answers: Ub Iwerks (UBB EYE-"works") [or Ubbe Ert Iwwerks; or U. B. Iwerks]
CalArts [or California Institute of the Arts; accept CalArts style]

bonuses.leadin: Sigmund Freud signed off several letters about psychoanalysis using the name of a character from this story, who hears tales of working in a slaughterhouse for Nicholas Snub-Nose. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this story. The title event of this story is probably imagined by a delirious man in Valladolid who appears in the preceding story in a collection, "The Deceitful Marriage," as he watches some animals outside his hospital window.
This Spanish author of "The Conversation of the Dogs" included comical animals like the horse Rocinante (ross-ee-NAN-tay) in Don Quixote (kee-HOH-tay).
"The Conversation of the Dogs" appears in this collection by Cervantes. Tomás Rodaja (roh-DAH-hah) believes he is going to shatter in this collection's story "The Lawyer of Glass."
answers: "The Conversation of the Dogs" [or "The Dialogue of the Dogs"; or "Dialogue between Cipión and Berganza"; or "El coloquio de los perros"]
formatted_answers: "The Conversation of the Dogs" [or "The Dialogue of the Dogs"; or "Dialogue between Cipión and Berganza"; or "El coloquio de los perros"]

bonuses.leadin: The output of a method named for André-Louis Cholesky (on-DRAY-loo-EE shoh-LES-kee) is the product of one of these things with its Hermitian (her-MISH-an) conjugate. For 10 points each:
parts: Singular value decomposition can be applied to what mathematical arrays of numbers?

This method of matrix decomposition, which writes a matrix as a product of two triangular matrices, is essentially the matrix formulation of Gaussian elimination. The standard method by which computers solve systems of linear equations uses this type of matrix decomposition.

QR (kew ar) decomposition, on the other hand, takes a matrix and writes it as a product of a matrix with this property and a triangular matrix. Multiplying a matrix with this property with its transpose gives the identity matrix.
answers: LU (ell "you") decomposition [or lower-upper decomposition or LU factorization or lower-upper factorization]
orthogonal matrix [or orthogonality or orthonormal matrix; prompt on unitary matrix or unitarity, asking "what is that called for real matrices?"]
formatted_answers: LU (ell "you") decomposition [or lower-upper decomposition or LU factorization or lower-upper factorization]
orthogonal matrix [or orthogonality or orthonormal matrix; prompt on unitary matrix or unitarity, asking "what is that called for real matrices?"]

bonuses.leadin: For 10 points each, answer the following about the writings of Oswald Spengler.
parts: The title of a multivolume book by Spengler published in the early 1920s predicts that this process will occur to the Western world.

The Decline of the West states that this substance is the only thing strong enough to overthrow the dominance of money. A speech by Otto von Bismarck claims that the "great questions of the day" will "be decided… by iron and" this substance.
An earlier book by Spengler contrasts the capitalist and socialist nature of these two powers. These two powers temporarily allied with each other in the Westminster Convention of 1756.
answers: decline [or downfall; or Untergang; or The Decline of the West; or Der Untergang des Abendlandes]
U.K. and Prussia [accept Great Britain or United Kingdom in place of "U.K."; accept answers in either order, but do not accept or prompt if only one answer is given]
formatted_answers: decline [or downfall; or Untergang; or The Decline of the West; or Der Untergang des Abendlandes]
U.K. and Prussia [accept Great Britain or United Kingdom in place of "U.K."; accept answers in either order, but do not accept or prompt if only one answer is given]

bonuses.leadin: Inscriptions on objects made of this material helped archaeologists identify the tomb of Fu Hao. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this material used to create mandolin-shaped daggers in ancient Liaoning (lee-ow-NING). The Shang and Zhou dynasties prominently used the taotie (TAO-tee) motif on ritual designs of this material.

Fu Hao may have collected many artifacts made of this material from the Liangzhu (lee-ongz-JOO) culture. In Chinese traditions, a mythological emperor who headed the pantheon was named for this green mineral.
These people created small jade artifacts known as "pig dragons." This Neolithic culture lived in the Liao (lee-ow) river basin and co-existed with the Yangshao (yong-SHOW) culture.
